titleStmt.title: Construction of Structural Mimetics of the Thyrotropin Receptor Intracellular Domain

affiliation.orgName: Department of Clinical Biochemistry and Pharmacology
Department of Clinical Biochemistry and Pharmacology

analytic.title: Construction of Structural Mimetics of the Thyrotropin Receptor Intracellular Domain

biblStruct.note: Submitted August 18, 2016, and accepted for publication November 2, 2016.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: The signaling of a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) is dictated by the complementary responsiveness of interacting intracellular effectors such as G proteins.
Many GPCRs are known to couple to more than one G protein subtype and induce a multitude of signaling pathways, although the in vivo relevance of particular pathways is mostly unrecognized.
Dissecting GPCR signaling in terms of the pathways that are activated will boost our understanding of the molecular fundamentals of hormone action.
The structural determinants governing the selectivity of GPCR/G protein coupling, however, remain obscure.
Here, we describe the design of soluble GPCR mimetics to study the details of the interplay between G-proteins and activators.
We constructed functional mimetics of the intracellular domain of a model GPCR, the thyrotropin receptor.

We based the construction on a unique scaffold, 6-Helix, an artificial protein that was derived from the elements of the trimer-of-hairpins structure of HIV gp41 and represents a bundle of six a-helices.

The 6-Helix scaffold, which endowed the substituted thyrotropin receptor intracellular domain elements with spatial constraints analogous to those found in native receptors, enabled the reconstitution of a microdomain that consists of intracellular loops 2 and 3, and is capable of binding and activating Ga-(s).
The 6-Helix-based mimetics could be used as a platform to study the molecular basis of GPCR/G protein recognition.

Such knowledge could help investigators develop novel therapeutic strategies for GPCR-related disorders by targeting the GPCR/G protein interfaces and counteracting cellular dysfunctions via focused tuning of GPCR signaling.
G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are the fundamental conduits of information from the extracellular space to the cytosol.

Malfunctions of ~100 GPCRs are known to be associated with different human diseases (1), including inflammation, infertility, metabolic and neurological disorders, viral infections, and cancer (2)(3)(4)(5)(6), and mutations in the thyrotropin receptor are most frequently associated with the occurrence of cancer (7).
Moreover, nearly 20% of tumors harbor mutations in GPCRs, and ~10% of cancer-related mutations have been mapped to G proteins (7).
Related work has not only concentrated on the physiological or pathophysiological mechanisms and pharmaceutical aspects of GPCR action but has also been extended to include stem cell research (8,9).
Notably, in this context, 365 nonolfactory human GPCRs are treated as potential drug targets (10) and ~40% of approved drugs target GPCRs (11).

Endogenous cues or drugs (agonists) that bind to the extracellular domain or to the upper part of the transmembrane domain (TMD) of the GPCR activate the receptors by inducing conformational changes, the exact mechanism of which remains elusive (12).

However, it is believed that some of the intramolecular constraints that stabilize the receptor's inactive (ground) state are removed, and structural flexibility is induced within the intracellular domain (ICD).
Endowed with the ability to explore a broader conformational space, the ICD of an activated GPCR may exist as an assembly of alternating conformations (conformers).
Some of these ICD conformers have surface epitopes that are exposed and hence are accessible for interaction with distinct effector molecules such as G proteins and arrestins.
These active conformers become stabilized and enriched by forming complexes with the effector molecule (affinity selection).
In this respect, agonist-induced ICD flexibility represents a crucial element of the GPCR activation process.
Signal routing from a GPCR to the intracellular effector molecules is dictated by the identity of the receptor-interacting G proteins, but many receptors couple to more than one G protein isoform.
The coupling can vary in a temporary, tissue-or ligand-specific manner (13,14).

Dissecting GPCR signaling on the basis of which pathways are activated will shed new light on the mechanism of hormonal action, which in turn will enable the development of novel strategies for the treatment of GPCR-related disorders, and more efficient and safer therapeutics that act in a signalpathway-specific manner.

Attempts to elucidate the exact nature of a receptor's active state have been compromised by the apparent inability of agonists to stabilize a receptor in a corresponding active conformation, which supports the idea that G proteins play active roles in stabilizing a receptor's active state via affinity selection (15)(16)(17).
A breakthrough in the field was achieved with the first crystallographic determination of the structure of the b2-adrenoceptor (b2-AR) in an active conformation stabilized by a G protein (18,19).

The structure helped elucidate the nature of the conformational changes associated with activation of the receptor, and revealed that the GPCR/G protein complex interface is formed by the receptor's intracellular loop 2 (ICL-2) and the juxtamembrane regions of the transmembrane helices 5 and 6 (TM5 and TM6).
However, the structure of the complex did not provide new insight into the molecular mechanism governing the selectivity of GPCR/G protein recognition.
For instance, a comparison of b2-AR sequences involved in the formation of the GPCR/G-(s) interface with corresponding sequences from other G-(s)-coupled receptors led to no consensus.

Moreover, both G-(s) and G-(i) isoforms effectively couple to b2-AR, despite the fact that the Ga-(s) and Ga-(i) subunits have only five amino acids in common among the 21 amino acids that constitute the b2-AR/G-(s) complex interface, and the majority of these five amino acids are located in the C-terminus, which is a highly conserved region among all G protein isoforms (19).

The crystal structure of the M3 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor was published in 2012 by Kruse et al. (20), who then compared the structural features of the existing GPCR crystal structures in an attempt to identify differences in the ICD of GPCRs specific to G-(i), G-(q), or G-(s).
In the GPCRs analyzed, the authors found a correlation between the selectivity of G-protein coupling and the distance between the intracellular termini of TM5 and TM6.

This finding is consistent with the idea that the selectivity of GPCR/G protein recognition is determined by both specific interresidue interactions and features related to the overall three-dimensional conformation of the ICD (20).

It appears, therefore, that to elucidate the fundamentals of the selectivity of GPCR/G protein recognition, a comprehensive analysis of the structure-activity relationships of multiple GPCR complexes with different G protein isoforms is required.
However, enormous technical difficulties associated with the isolation of functional receptors in quantities required for direct structural studies effectively impede progress in the field.
In this work, we addressed this problem by constructing functional mimetics of the GPCR ICD.

We demonstrated that by using a soluble scaffold that furnishes peptides derived from the GPCR ICD with spatial constraints similar to those found in native receptors, we were able to facilitate the reconstitution of a native-like G protein-recognition epitope.

As a model GPCR, we used thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR), a GPCR that has well-documented promiscuous G protein-coupling behavior and is able to activate all known G protein isoforms (21)(22)(23).
The respective physiological/pathological consequences of the activation of individual isoforms of G proteins by TSHR, however, remain unclear.
The gene encoding for TSHR is highly mutable (24), and TSHR mutations have been identified as a cause of acquired, hereditary, and congenital thyroid diseases (25).
Multiple mutations known to affect TSHR functions, both artificial and naturally occurring, have been shown to alter the profile of G protein coupling of this receptor (26).
Some of these mutations have been mapped to ICL-2 and ICL-3, which are the ICD elements that are directly involved in G protein recognition and activation (19,(27)(28)(29)(30).
The unique functional properties of TSHR make it a well-suited model for studying the structural determinants of GPCR/G protein recognition.

div.head: Purification of the G protein subunits Ga-(s) and Ga-(i2)

p.s: To improve expression, the genes encoding 6His-tagged bovine Ga-(s) (short) and Ga-(i2) were recloned from pML1213HisGs and MLHisGi2 plasmids (a gift from Dr. Maurine Linder, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY) into pHis1 plasmid (31) to yield the pHis-Gs and pHis-Gi2 plasmids, respectively.

The G proteins were expressed and purified from Escherichia coli (BL21-DE3) as described previously (32) and stored in 50 mM HEPES buffer, pH 8.0, 0.5 mM EDTA, 2 mM dithiothreitol (DTT), 50 mM guanosine diphosphate (GDP), and 10% glycerol at À20 C under argon.

div.head: Purification of the eGFP-Ga-(q) and eGFP-Ga-(i2) fusion proteins

p.s: The pCIS plasmid encoding a wild-type Ga-(q) was a gift from Dr. Nina Wettschureck (Max Planck Institute for Heart and Lung Research, Bad Nauheim, Germany).
The Gnaq gene was subcloned into the expression vector pET28-eGFP (Novagen, Germany) at the C-terminus of the eGFP gene.

Our purposes in constructing the eGFP fusion plasmid were to ensure Ga-(q) solubility during its expression and purification from E. coli, and to label the protein fluorescently for subsequent binding experiments (see below).

The eGFP-Ga-(q) fusion was expressed in E. coli (BL21) by growing cells at 30 C in a rich medium (2% tryptone, 1% yeast extract, 0.5% NaCl, 0.2% glycerol, 50 mM KH 2 PO 4 (pH 7.2), and 100 mg/mL kanamycin) to an OD of 0.6-0.7,
followed by addition of 0.5 mM isopropyl b-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside (Sigma-Aldrich Israel Ltd., Rehovot, Israel) and subsequent incubation at 20 C overnight.

The cells were separated by centrifugation at 4000 Â g for 20 min, disrupted by sonication in a loading buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 0.1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 20 mM b-mercaptoethanol, 0.1 mg/mL lysozyme, and antiprotease inhibitor mixture (Mercury, Rosh-Ha'ayin, Israel)), incubated for 30 min with stirring in the presence of 5 mM MgSO 4 and 3-5 mg of DNase I (Sigma-Aldrich) on ice, and centrifuged at 10,000 Â g for 1 h at 4 C.

The supernatant was loaded on a 5 mL HiTrap FF column (GE Healthcare Life Sciences, Pittsburgh, PA) equilibrated with the loading buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 0.1 M NaCl, and 20 mM b-mercaptoethanol).

The column was washed with 5 column volumes of a washing buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 0.5 M NaCl, 20 mM b-mercaptoethanol, and 10 mM imidazole) and eluted by a linear 10-500 mM gradient of imidazole in 50 mM Tris-HCl buffer, pH 8.0, 0.1 M NaCl, 20 mM b-mercaptoethanol, 10% glycerol.
The peak fractions were dialyzed overnight at 4 C against a 50 mM Tris-HCl buffer, pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM DTT, 2 mM GDP, and 10% glycerol.

Dialyzed pure protein was washed with a storage buffer (50 mM HEPES, pH 8.0, 0.5 mM EDTA, 2 mM DTT, 50 mM GDP, and 10% glycerol), concentrated by ultrafiltration (Amicon Ultra 30K, Mercury), and stored at À20 C. The eGFP-Ga-(i2) fusion protein was purified in a similar manner.
Purification of 6-Helix-based TSHR ICD mimetics and 6-Helix scaffold protein
The genes encoding for 6-Helix-(III)-IL2/3, 6-Helix-(III)-IL2, 6-Helix-(III)-IL3, and 6-Helix-(II)-IL2/3 were cloned into the pET28(c) vector (Novagen, Madison, WI).

All of the genes were expressed in E. coli (BL21) by growing cells at 30 C in a rich medium (2% tryptone, 1% yeast extract, 0.5% NaCl, 0.2% glycerol, 50 mM KH 2 PO 4 (pH 7.2), and 100 mg/mL kanamycin) to an OD of 0.6-0.7,

followed by addition of 0.5 mM isopropyl b-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside (Sigma-Aldrich) and further incubation overnight at 20 C. The cells were separated by centrifugation at 4000 Â g for 20 min, disrupted by sonication in a loading buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 0.5 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 2 mM benzamidine chloride, and antiprotease inhibitor mixture (Mercury)), and centrifuged at 10,000 Â g for 30 min at 4 C.

In the case of 6-Helix-(III)-IL2, 6-Helix-(III)-IL3, and 6-Helix (the plasmid p-6Helix was a gift from Dr. Michael Root, Thomas Jefferson University, Philadelphia, PA), the supernatant was loaded on a 5 mL HiTrap FF column (GE Healthcare Life Sciences) equilibrated with the loading buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 0.5 M NaCl, and 10 mM imidazole).
In the case of 6-Helix-(III)-IL2/3, the protein-containing fraction was enriched by ammonium sulfate fractionalization.

A precipitate that formed after 15 min of incubation on ice in the presence of 18% ammonium sulfate was redissolved in 90 mL of loading buffer and applied to a 30 mL Ni-NTA agarose column (Qiagen, Germantown, MD).

The column was washed with 5 column volumes of a washing buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 0.5 M NaCl, and 20 mM imidazole) and eluted by a linear 20-400 mM imidazole gradient in 50 mM Tris-HCl buffer, pH 8.0, 0.1 M NaCl.
The peak fractions were dialyzed overnight at 4 C against a storage buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, and 0.1 M NaCl), concentrated by ultrafiltration, and stored at À20 C under argon.

div.head: Circular dichroism spectroscopy analysis

p.s: Circular dichroism (CD) analyses were carried out at 25 C in 10 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 8.0, at a protein concentration of 0.2 mg/mL.
The ellipticity was measured between 200 and 260 nm with a 1 nm bandwidth and 20 nm/min scanning speed using a Jasco J-810 spectropolarimeter (Jasco, Easton, MD).
The molar ellipticity, [Q], was calculated using the formula

div.formula: [Q] ¼ Q Â MRW/(c Â l Â 10)

p.s: , where Q is the measured ellipticity (mdeg), c is the protein concentration (g/mL), l is the optical path length (OPL; 0.1 cm), and MRW ¼ Mw/(n À 1) is the average molecular mass of residues in the protein (where Mw is the protein molecular mass (g/mol), and n is the number of amino acids).
Secondary-structure analysis was performed using the CDNN CD spectra deconvolution software (Applied Photophysics, Beverly, MA).

Purified Ga-(s) and Ga-(i2) subunits dissolved in phosphate-buffered saline (10 mM GDP and 5% glycerol) were fluorescently labeled with NT-495-NHS dye (lysine chemistry) using a Monolith NT protein labeling kit (Blue-NHS; NanoTemper Technologies, M€ unchen, Germany) at a 1:5 protein/dye molar ratio for 1 h at room temperature according to the manufacturer's instructions.

Interactions between the labeled Ga subunits (200 nM) and the mimetics were measured in a binding buffer (50 mM HEPES, pH 8.0, 0.1 mM tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine, 0.1 M NaCl, 0.01% Tween-20, and 0.2 mg/mL bovine serum albumin (BSA)) after a 1 h incubation at room temperature by infrared-laser thermophoresis using a Monolit 115 instrument (NanoTemper Technologies).
Interactions of eGFP-Ga-(q) subunits with the mimetics were assessed in a binding buffer containing 0.05% Tween-20 and 0.5 mg/mL BSA.
The binding data were analyzed via a nonlinear regression using a logistic (three-parameter) function implemented in the Prism 6 program (GraphPad).

The rate of free phosphate release during GTP hydrolysis catalyzed by Ga subunits was determined at 30 C in 50 mL of 50 mM Tris/HCl, pH 8.0, reaction buffer containing 0.3 mM GDP, 0.1 M NaCl, 0.5 mM MgCl 2 , 0.1 mM tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine, and 0.1% CHAPSO.
Molecular-grade water was used.

After 15 min, the reaction was stopped by addition of a 1/10 volume of 5% H 2 SO 4 and analyzed for the presence of free phosphate using a PiColorLock Phosphate Colorimetric Detection System kit (Innova Biosciences, Cambridge, UK).
The 6-Helix-(III)-IL2/3 mimetic, but not the other mimetics described in this study, was copurified with a nonzero amount of self GTPase activity, which interfered with its functional evaluation.

Before GTPase activity analyses were conducted, this contaminating GTPase activity was heat inactivated by incubating a 6 mg/mL solution of the 6-Helix-(III)-IL2/3 mimetic at 65 C for 30 min, followed by centrifugation at 20,000 Â g for 5 min.
Protein concentrations were measured by the Bradford method, using BSA as the standard.

We hypothesized that by endowing the GPCR ICL-derived peptides with the appropriate spatial constraints, we could facilitate the reconstitution of a composite G protein-recognition conformational epitope.
To guide the scaffold selection process, we used an experimental structure of the complex formed by an activated b 2 -AR and the G-(s) protein (19).

An artificial protein designated 6-Helix, which is a bundle composed of six a-helices connected by short flexible linkers (Gly/Ser), was derived from the elements of a trimer-of-hairpins structure of the HIV glycoprotein gp41 (formed by the NH 2 -and COOH-terminal regions of three gp41 molecules) assembled during the virus-cell fusion process (33).
6-Helix is an exceptionally stable protein that can be produced in high quantities in a bacterial host.

The interhelix sequences at each of the two inequivalent edges of the 6-Helix bundle (designated side II and side III) can be replaced by sequences derived from the GPCR ICD (Fig. S1 A in the Supporting Material).

Only side III, however, offers a unique topology of the helical termini that enables the ICL-2-and ICL-3-derived sequences to be placed in a spatial arrangement similar to that found in the native GPCR (19) (Fig. 1; Table 1; Table S1).

We used a homology model of the TSHR/G-(s) complex (34) built on the template of the b 2 -AR/G-(s) complex structure to guide the selection of TSHR elements contributing to the formation of a putative TSHR/G-(s) interface.

To build 6-Helix-based TSHR ICD mimetics, we replaced the interhelical linkers on side III of the scaffold with TSHR sequences corresponding to ICL-2 (TLERWYAITFAMRLDRKIRLRH) and ICL-3 (including the TM5 and TM6 juxtamembrane regions, YVKIYITVRNPQYNPGDKDTKIATRMA).

Short, flexible linkers (GGSGG) were introduced at each side of the inserts to soften the spatial constraints imposed by the scaffold, and this process yielded a chimeric protein designated 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 (Fig. S1 B in the Supporting Material).
Structural and functional evaluation of 6-Helix-based ICD mimetics CD structural analysis.
The 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 construct was expressed in E. coli as a 6His-tagged soluble protein and purified to homogeneity by Ni-affinity chromatography.
As inferred from the CD spectroscopic analysis, the helical bundle core of the original 6-Helix scaffold was largely preserved in the TSHR ICD mimetics (Fig. S2 in the Supporting Material).
The calculated 29% decrease in the a-helical content of the 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 mimetic compared with the 6-Helix scaffold (63.8% vs. 89.6%)
could be attributed, at least partially, to the insertion of the unstructured loop regions (IL-2, IL-3, and flexible linkers), which in total account for 18% of the mimetic's sequence.
However, the possibility that the insertions had some destabilizing effects on the overall structure cannot be ruled out.
We also generated and characterized a TSHR ICD mimetic, designated 6-Helix II-ICL2/3, in which the aforementioned elements of the ICD were incorporated into side II of the 6-Helix scaffold.

The topology of the helical termini at side II does not support the placement of loopderived sequences in a spatial configuration similar to that found in native GPCRs (Table S1 in the Supporting Material).

As revealed by the CD analysis, the structure of the a-helical core of the 6-Helix II-ICL2/3 mimetic is significantly more destabilized (a-helical content: 42%) compared with that of the side III-based 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 mimetic (Fig. S2 in the Supporting Material).
G protein binding.
We next used a microscale thermophoresis technique (35) to investigate the ability of the TSHR ICD mimetics to bind recombinant purified Ga subunits.
TSHR is remarkable in its ability to activate all known G protein isoforms (21)(22)(23).
Fluorescently labeled Ga subunits (Ga-(s), Ga-(i2), and Ga-(q)) were titrated with increasing concentrations (0.1-100 mM) of unlabeled mimetic proteins.
As shown in Fig. 2, the side III-based 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 mimetic bound the Ga-(s) subunit with a calculated K d of 3.0 mM.
In contrast, the side II-based 6-Helix II-ICL2/3 mimetic bound the Ga-(s) subunit with much lower affinity (K d z 20 mM).
Within the concentration range tested, no specific binding to Ga-(i2), labeled similarly to Ga-(s) by lysine chemistry, was detected (not shown).

To test whether lysine modification could affect the interactions, we constructed a fusion protein in which Ga-(i2) was fused to the C-terminus of eGFP, to effect labeling without modifying the protein's structure.
No specific binding of the 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 mimetics to eGFP-Ga-(i2) fusion was observed.
Because of a solubility issue, the native form of Ga-(q) cannot be produced in E. coli.

Therefore, Ga-(q) was expressed and isolated in a soluble and catalytically active form (as revealed by a GTPase hydrolysis Average interhelical distances (A ˚) on the cytoplasmic side of the TMD bundle of the b 2 -AR in complex with G-(s) (19) were measured at the level of an imaginary cross section corresponding to the inner membrane edge (H8 level).

b Average interhelical distances (A ˚) were measured on side III of an equilibrated structure of the 6-Helix scaffold built on the template of the crystal structure of the HIV gp41 core (PDB: 1F23 ( 58)).
TM colors are as in Fig. 1.
assay) as an eGFP fusion protein.
No specific binding of the 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 mimetics to eGFP-Ga-(q) fusion was observed (not shown).
Stimulation of GTPase activity of G proteins.

We further tested the modality of interaction of the TSHR ICD mimetics with G proteins by measuring the effect of 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 on the steady-state rate of GTP hydrolysis catalyzed by the recombinant Ga subunits.

If ICD mimetics such as activated GPCRs do indeed function as nucleotide exchange factors in facilitating the release of bound GDP (a rate-limiting step in Ga-catalyzed GTPase activity), binding will result in increased rates of GTP hydrolysis.

The availability of large quantities of target proteins enabled us to use a colorimetric GTPase assay to quantify the amounts of inorganic phosphate that were liberated in the course of GTP hydrolysis.
As shown in Fig. 3, the 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 mimetics stimulated the GTPase activity of the Ga-(s) subunits in a dose-dependent manner.

To probe the respective contributions of the individual TSHR ICLs to the observed GTPase activity, we constructed 6-Helix side III-based ICD mimetics that contained either ICL-2 (6-Helix III-ICL2) or ICL-3 (6-Helix III-ICL3).
Both single-loop mimetics were able to stimulate the GTPase activity of Ga-(s) with a low potency (Fig. 3).

Thus, the simultaneous presence of the ICL-2 and ICL-3 elements in the ICD mimetic considerably improved the recognition of Ga-(s), manifested in a decreased apparent K d of the complex, calculated from the GTPase activation data.
In agreement with the results of binding experiments, the 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 mimetic was ineffective in stimulating GTP hydrolysis catalyzed by either Ga-(i2) or Ga-(q).

div.head: GPCR mimetics

p.s: Previous studies have demonstrated that isolated peptides derived from the ICDs of GPCRs can bind and activate G proteins (36)(37)(38).
However, when removed from their structural context, isolated peptides may not accurately convey the whole scope of functionalities attributed to the GPCR ICDs.

The structural determinants of G protein-coupling specificity may include subtle features of the secondary and tertiary structures (19), which are components of a composite functional epitope comprising sequences distant from each other in the receptor's primary structure (20).
It is also possible for some elements of the interaction interface to play a permissive role in recognition (positive specificity) while others exert a prohibitive effect (negative specificity).
The whole scope of these features may not be properly presented in isolated peptides.
Similar limitations may apply for ICD mimetics, in which ICL-derived sequences are arranged in tandem (38).
Assuming a conformational character for the G proteinrecognition epitope, the selection of a proper scaffolding protein is deemed to be crucial for constructing an optimal ICD mimetic.
Spatial constraints similar to those imposed

div.formula: V ¼ (1 À x) Â Vi þ x Â Vf,

p.s: where Vi is the basal rate of Ga-catalyzed GTP hydrolysis, Vf is the rate of GTP hydrolysis catalyzed by the Ga/ICD-mimetic complex (at saturation), and x is the fraction of Ga subunit in the complex with ICD mimetics (x ¼ [GM]/[Gat]).

Here, GM is the Ga/ICD-mimetic complex whose concentration was explicitly calculated from the equation ð½MtÀGM,½GatÀGMÞ=½GM ¼ K d , where Gat and Mt are the total assay concentrations of the Ga subunits (5 mM) and ICD mimetics, respectively.
The original 6-Helix scaffold protein used as a negative control in the experiments did not show any specific activation (not shown).
Values presented are the means 5 SD of three independent experiments performed in duplicates.
The apparent K d values calculated for Ga-(s) complexes with 6-Helix III-ICL2/3, 6-Helix III-ICL2, and 6-Helix III-ICL3 mimetics were 0.7, 9.6, and 11.5 mM, respectively.
by the TMD of a membrane receptor would facilitate the reconstitution of the ICD epitope in its three-dimensional complexity.
Such mimetics would be expected to imitate the functional properties of a native receptor more closely than isolated ICD-derived peptides or peptides arranged in tandem.

Guided by the structure of the b-AR/G-(s) protein complex, we identified 6-Helix, a six-a-helix bundle protein that is characterized on one side (side III) by a helical termini topology similar to that found on the intracellular side of the TMD of an activated GPCR.
In the side III-based TSHR ICD mimetic, the ICL-2 and ICL-3 inserts contributed synergistically to the mimetic's ability to stimulate Ga-(s)-catalyzed GTP hydrolysis (Fig. 3).
In addition, the presence of the ICL-2 and ICL-3 elements in the side III mimetics resulted in only a mild or no structural perturbation the a-helical core.
In contrast, in the side II mimetics, in which a native-like placement of the ICL elements is not possible, a pronounced destabilization of the helical core resulted.
Accordingly, the side II ICD mimetics bound the G protein with a significantly lower affinity than the side III mimetics.

Altogether, these results are consistent with the idea that in the side III mimetics, the ICL elements assume a distinct conformation that is efficient in both binding and activating the target G protein.
Thus, by endowing individual ICD sequences with native-like spatial constraints, one can facilitate the reconstitution of a composite G protein-recognition epitope.
The bg subunits are known to play a regulatory role in G protein signaling.

In the absence of an activated receptor, the bg subunits attenuate GDP dissociation from the Ga subunit, preventing its subsequent activation by GTP, and therefore they are required for efficient GPCR/G protein coupling (39,40).
Consequently, using isolated Ga subunits in the analysis of steady-state kinetics of GTP hydrolysis may result in an underestimation of the ability of the ICD mimetics to stimulate GTPase activity.
In cell-based assays, the TSHR exhibited a broad G protein-coupling profile (21)(22)(23).
In this study, however, the 6-Helix-based TSHR ICD mimetics were able to recognize and activate the G-(s) isoform, but failed to do so with the G-(q) and G-(i) isoforms.
To interpret these results, one should take several important considerations into account.
First, this study was carried out using isolated Ga subunits.
According to the crystal structure of the b-AR/Ga(s)bg complex (18,19), the bg subunits are not directly involved in the formation of the GPCR/G protein interface.
However, because of the stabilizing effect of the bg subunits on the Ga structure, we cannot rule out the possibility that their presence affected the selectivity of GPCR/G protein recognition.

Second, a comparative analysis of the structural features in a manifold of GPCR crystal structures led Kruse et al. (20) to conclude that one of the factors affecting the selectivity of GPCR/G protein coupling is the distance between the intracellular termini of TM5 and TM6.
According to this study, distances of 9-10, 10-12, and 13-14 A ˚are characteristic of G-(q/11), G-(s), and G-(i/o)-coupled receptors, respectively.

In the case of TSHR (or any other receptor with a broad profile of G protein coupling), this implies that signal routing would require the action of several biased agonists to regulate the TM5-to-TM6 distance.

For TSHR, however, biased endogenous agonists are so far unknown, leading to the speculation that upon activation, the receptor undergoes a complete relaxation of the ICD to enable competitive binding of various G protein isoforms on the basis of affinity selection modulated by the availability of particular effectors.

The idea of complete ICD relaxation under activation entails the possibility that a relatively small number of interhelical constraints stabilize the promiscuous receptors in their inactive (ground) state compared with the receptors with a narrow G protein-coupling profile.
This is consistent with experimental observations that the TSHR is particularly susceptible to mutations that result in constitutive receptor activation (41).

In the side III 6-Helix ICD mimetics, the distance between the termini of the helices corresponding to the receptor's TM5 and TM6 (to which the ICL-3 element is attached) is ~11-12 A ˚(measured in an equilibrated structure of the 6-Helix scaffold; Table 1).
In the mimetics, the ICL-3 sequence is attached to the helical termini through flexible linkers (GGSGG), softening the distance constraints imposed by the scaffold.

The presence of excessive flexibility in the linkers, however, may have an unpredictable effect of trapping the ICD structure in a certain conformation compatible with binding of a specific G protein isoform (G-(s) in this case).

Research is ongoing to examine the effect of structural flexibility on the specificity of G protein recognition by constructing a panel of TSHR ICD mimetics in which flexible linker(s) are replaced by sequences predisposed to the formation of rigid a-helical structures (e.g., poly-Ala).

Third, although according to the structure of the b2-AR/ G-(s) complex, the ICL-1 and the C-terminal helix-8 (H8) are not part of the GPCR/G protein interface, increasing evidence indicates that the role of these ICD elements in G protein binding may not be dispensable.

For instance, in rhodopsin (42) and muscarinic M1R (43), H8 was shown to be important for G-protein coupling, and the H8 of the muscarinic M3R cross-linked to Ca-(q) in an agonistdependent manner (44).

Moreover, an NMR study of activated m-opioid receptor suggested that ICL-1 and H8 may play roles in the initial interaction with the G-protein, whereas the engagement of TM5 and TM6 occurs during later steps of the complex formation process (17).
Thus, the formation of the GPCR/G protein complex may be a multistep process in which different elements of the ICD engage the effector G protein sequentially.

In sequential binding, the intermediate interaction steps may kinetically facilitate the formation of the final complex by presenting the G protein in a correct orientation to its ultimate binding epitope.
In each of these putative intermediate steps, selectivity filters that ultimately affect the specificity of G protein coupling may apply.
In this case, our ICD mimetics lacking both ICL-1 and H8 would be deficient in their ability to recapitulate G protein binding specificity correctly.
Fourth, the results may reflect a real paradigm of TSHR/G protein coupling.
Simultaneous activation of both G-(s) and G-(i) signaling pathways in the same cell would apparently be counterproductive, and it is conceivable that these processes are resolved in time.

A possible sequence of events may include G-(s) activation followed by an alteration of the receptor's structure by a third-party effector molecule (e.g., a cAMP-dependent kinase) that renders the receptor competent for G-(i) coupling (37).
A switch in the receptor's coupling specificity may also be achieved by the recruitment of an auxiliary protein(s) that promotes specific GPCR/G protein interactions.

A long-known phenomenon of TSHR-mediated signaling is the different potencies with which TSH activates the G-(s) and G-(q) signaling pathways, with the G-(q) pathway requiring higher receptor occupancy than the G-(s) pathway (45).
A similar phenomenon has been reported for some other GPCRs, including those for calcitonin (46,47) and secretin (48).
Allen et al. (49) demonstrated that in a spare receptor-free system, the difference in potencies could be explained by homodimerization of TSHRs.

According to the authors, stimulation of G-(s)-mediated cAMP formation requires TSH binding to only one of the monomers in the preexisting homodimer, whereas activation of G-(q)mediated phosphoinositide hydrolysis requires both TSHR monomers to be occupied by the hormone.

There is also a possibility that the receptor dimerization is TSH dependent, with Ga-(s)-coupled monomers prevailing at low TSH concentrations and Ga-(q)-coupled dimers prevailing at high TSH concentrations.
Thus, G protein coupling specificity may depend on the oligomeric state of the receptor, a feature that may not be easily recapitulated by the ICD mimetics.

Although the current generation of 6-Helix-based TSHR-ICD mimetics is unable to recapitulate the apparent promiscuous G protein-coupling behavior of TSHR, the mimetics may prove to be a valuable tool in a variety of biomedical applications, as discussed below.

div.head: Biochemical approaches to elucidate the structural basis of GPCR/G protein recognition

p.s: Although the amino acid sequence of the ICD is the least conserved region of the receptor, an intriguing feature of GPCR signal transduction is that numerous receptor types and subtypes are capable of coupling to the same G protein.

It is generally accepted that because Ala-scan mutagenesis is restricted in its ability to sample the available chemical and structural space, it is therefore unsuitable for comprehensive analyses of the structure-activity relationships of protein-protein complex formation (50,51).

The alternative quantitative-saturation approach, in which the chemical and structural diversity of the whole set of 20 natural amino acids is evaluated at each position of the binding interface, has revealed that functionally important interface positions are highly tolerant to mutations, and that the acceptable substitutions are highly context dependent and neither chemically nor evolutionarily conserved (51).

This paradigm can explain the fact that receptors with similar G protein coupling preferences exhibit little sequence conservation at the putative receptor/effector interface, and that low sequence similarity is a characteristic of different G protein isoforms coupled to the same receptor (19,20).
The low chemical and structural conservation of functionally important residues confounds their identification, complicating elucidation of the structural basis of GPCR/G protein recognition.

Our preliminary results demonstrated that 6-Helix-based TSHR ICD mimetics genetically fused to the mating-yeast agglutinin protein could be efficiently expressed on the surface of yeast cells (outside the cell wall) in a folded, G protein-binding-competent conformation (unpublished results).

This will enable investigators to combine yeast surface display technique (52,53) with high-throughput fluorescence-activated cell sorting and deep sequencing to map the structural determinants of GPCR/G protein recognition using ICD mimetic libraries in which the ICL-2 and ICL-3 sequences are randomized, with a G protein as the screening target.
For each randomized position, the amino acid frequency distribution can be determined and analyzed against an array of aligned GPCR sequences with known G protein coupling profiles.
Such an analysis would allow the ICD functional epitope(s) responsible for G protein recognition to be mapped.

div.head: Biophysical approaches to elucidate the properties of GPCR/G protein interfaces

p.s: The tremendous technical difficulties associated with GPCR expression and isolation have precluded a structural evaluation of whole GPCR/G protein complexes by x-ray crystallography, and therefore, to date, the structure of only one such complex, b2-AR/G-(s), has been solved (19).
Soluble ICD mimetics, which in principle, could be constructed for any GPCR, represent a practical solution to this problem.

Considering the artificial character of the ICD mimetics, any conclusions drawn from the aforementioned biochemical or biophysical evaluations should be corroborated by functional assays employing membrane receptors.

Pepducins, lipid-functionalized peptides derived from elements of the GPCR ICD, are cell-permeable compounds that function intracellularly by modulating the signal transduction from a GPCR to a G protein via an allosteric mechanism (54).
Pepducins may have therapeutic applications in the treatment of GPCR-related disorders.
To date, pepducins for more than 15 different GPCRs have been constructed, and some have entered the clinical trial stage of development (55).

Pepducin sequences with improved characteristics or novel functionalities could be generated from ICD-mimetic variants with improved G protein binding properties selected by means of the yeast surface display.
High-throughput screening platform to identify compounds that interfere with the formation of GPCR/G protein complexes

Because the conventional orthosteric ligand-binding pocket in the upper part of the TMD is characterized by a high degree of structural similarity among the GPCR family members (56,57), the development of selective drugs is an increasingly challenging task.
The high variability of the ICD sequences, however, provides an opportunity for the development of selective drugs by targeting the GPCR/G protein interface.
Compounds interfering with the formation of specific GPCR/G protein complexes may also possess signaling-pathway-specific properties.

A proximity detection system monitoring the formation of an ICD-mimetic/ G protein complex could be used as a high-throughput screening platform to identify compounds selectively interfering with specific GPCR/G protein interaction.
Two figures and one table are available at http://www.biophysj.org/
biophysj/supplemental/S0006-3495(16)31001-3.

planned experiments, analyzed data, and wrote the manuscript.
G.K. planned experiments and wrote the manuscript.
O.P., T.Z., and M.V. performed experiments and analyzed data.
FIGURE 1 The 6-Helix scaffold as a soluble mimetic of the GPCR TMD.
(A) b 2 -AR/G-(s) complex crystal structure (PDB: 3SN6) (19).
ICL-2 and ICL-3 are shown in pink, and Ga-(s) is shown as light purple ribbons.
(B) The structure of the 6-Helix scaffold (33) reconstituted from the crystal structure of the HIV gp41 core (PDB: 1F23 (58)) is oriented so that side III faces the viewer.
The 6-Helix helices used for insertion of the ICL-2 and ICL-3 elements of GPCR are colored according to their counterpart GPCR TM helices in (A).
To see this figure in color, go online.
FIGURE 2 The 6-Helix side III TSHR ICD mimetics bind Ga-(s) more efficiently than the side II mimetics.

Binding was measured by microscale thermophoresis after a 1 h incubation of 200 nM fluorescently labeled Ga-(s) at room temperature with increasing concentrations of unlabeled 6-Helix III-ICL2/3 (side III mimetic) or 6-Helix II-ICL2/3 (side II mimetic).
The original 6-Helix scaffold protein, which was used as a negative control in the experiments, did not demonstrate any specific binding (these data were not plotted due to a low signal/noise ratio).
The data were analyzed by the Prism 6 program (GraphPad) using a nonlineal regression and the standard slope sigmoidal function.
Values presented are the means 5 SD of three independent experiments performed in duplicates.
FIGURE 3 The 6-Helix TSHR ICD mimetics stimulate Ga-(s)-catalyzed GTP hydrolysis.

Recombinant Ga-(s) subunits (5 mM) were preincubated with increasing concentrations of 6-Helix TSHR ICD mimetics for 30 min at room temperature and the reaction was started by the addition of 300 mM GTP.
After a 15 min incubation at 30 C, Pi liberated by the Ga-catalyzed GTPase reaction was measured calorimetrically using a PiColorLock reagent (Innova Biosciences).

The data were analyzed by the Prism 6 program using the function V¼ (1 À x) Â Vi þ x Â Vf,where Vi is the basal rate of Ga-catalyzed GTP hydrolysis, Vf is the rate of GTP hydrolysis catalyzed by the Ga/ICD-mimetic complex (at saturation), and x is the fraction of Ga subunit in the complex with ICD mimetics (x ¼ [GM]/[Gat]).

Here, GM is the Ga/ICD-mimetic complex whose concentration was explicitly calculated from the equation ð½MtÀGM,½GatÀGMÞ=½GM ¼ K d , where Gat and Mt are the total assay concentrations of the Ga subunits (5 mM) and ICD mimetics, respectively.
The original 6-Helix scaffold protein used as a negative control in the experiments did not show any specific activation (not shown).
Values presented are the means 5 SD of three independent experiments performed in duplicates.
The apparent K d values calculated for Ga-(s) complexes with 6-Helix III-ICL2/3, 6-Helix III-ICL2, and 6-Helix III-ICL3 mimetics were 0.7, 9.6, and 11.5 mM, respectively.
